item.title: Speed Up Your Site with a CDN: Content Delivery Network Essentials
item.description: One scenario where I need a CDN is for dynamically requesting static JavaScript files on my website. Hosting these large JS files myself would significantly impact my bandwidth usage since my host charges based on traffic volume. Using a CDN helps solve this issue by distributing requests across its worldwide network of data centers. Not only does this improve access speeds by caching files closer to users, it also reduces my origin server load and bandwidth costs. With assets offloaded to the CDN, my website performance is optimized for a better user experience while keeping infrastructure expenses down. In summary, a CDN provides clear benefits in both performance and savings for serving the static files required by my application at global scale.

item.title: Striking a Balance Between Speed and Compression Ratio: The Relationship Between Compression Algorithms and Formats
item.description: Some common compression formats include zip, rar, and 7z. Common compression algorithms include gzip, brotli, zstd, lz4, pigz, isa-l, and pzstd. However, what are the relationships between these? How can one strike a balance between compression speed and ratio? What is the relationship between compression algorithms and formats?

item.title: Exploring JDK 21 New Feature: Virtual Threads
item.description: JDK 21, the latest LTS release of OpenJDK, introduces an exciting new feature called Virtual Threads. In this blog post, we will delve into the details of this feature and explore how it enhances the scalability and performance of concurrent applications.

item.title: Tracking SQLite Database Changes in Git
item.description: SQLite stores data in binary. If you run cat mydb.sqlite, you’ll see a bunch of gibberish that doesn’t resemble structured data at all. If you want to track changes and updates to a database using Git, you won’t be able to see full diffs by default.

item.title: Color Grading DJI D-Cinelike Footage in DaVinci Resolve
item.description: This blog post will focus on color grading in DaVinci Resolve. It will introduce DJI’s D-Cinelike, D-Log color profiles, Sony camera S-Log, and explain the differences between these log formats and normal color profiles. The goal is to provide a tutorial for colorists on how to get the most out of log footage when color grading in DaVinci Resolve.
